Package roadway_dispersion

The roadway_dispersion package contains the core routines of the UCD 2001 roadway dispersion model.

See:
          Description

Class Summary
constants Overview
The constants class stores all roadway dispersion constants into one class.
coordinate Overview
The coordinate class stores and accesses cartesian coordinates (x,y,z) and provides member functions such as dot, horizontal_angle, and norm to perform simple operations on the coordinates.
dispersion Overview
Class dispersion stores all the variables used to evaluate the lateral dispersion and the huang dispersion equation.
highway_link Overview
highway_link is a link type developed specifically to emulate the release characteristics of the GM sulfate dispersion experiment.
highway_point_spacing Overview
This class facilitates the creatation of the point array that represents the emissions from a highway_link object.
huang Overview
The huang class provides a convenient way to clarify the evaluation of the huang dispersion equation by grouping fetch, latteral distance, elevation of source, and receptor elevation information for of a point-receptor pair.
link Overview
link is the superclass for all types of roadway links.
point Overview
The point class creates a point source based on huangs theory of dispersion in turbulent shear flow (Atmoshperic Environment 1979).
point_vector point_vector class provides a modular and flexible way to generate point source locations for use in the huang/roadway dispersion model.
pollutant_type Overview
The pollutant type class is a simple way to store information about pollutants.
receptor Overview
The receptor class represents a person or target coordinate near a roadway.
site_description Overview
This class is used as a container to store information about a sampling site.
 

Package roadway_dispersion Description

The roadway_dispersion package contains the core routines of the UCD 2001 roadway dispersion model. This package includes routines that define coordinates, receptors, links, pollutants, and other objects essential to dispersion modeling.

Version:
1.0 (October 2001)
Author:
Tony Held
